head.supplied: Melbourne bot Garden ¶ 24/4/69 ¶ I feel very much indebted, dear Prof. Parlatore, for your great kindness in sending me your photogram ¶ , ¶ which I shall treasure much. I am also obliged for your go...

div.p:
I feel very much indebted, dear Prof. Parlatore, for your great kindness in sending me your photogram, which I shall treasure much. I am also obliged for your goodness in forwarding the printed list of seeds of the Florence Garden, one so rich in treasures. I first contemplated to make an extract of the kinds new to Australian culture, but it would have been such a long array of names, that I finally thought it best merely [to]
editorial addition — MS torn.
mention my wishes generally. Any seeds of trees and shrubs (exclusive of Australian species) will be welcome here, because few kinds are in cultivation, which bear already here seeds. Hence I have to rely constantly on new importations to maintain the supply of the plants for our public cemeteries, church- and school- grounds. — Seeds of none of the Greenhouse plants of [orna]ment,
MS torn. of special structural interest or of particular utility will come amiss. In cases, where I already have the plants, such seeds (if fresh) will serve for interchanges with other institutions. I may remark, that I have as yet not a single Plant of Pistacia vera and only one species of Papyrus. The seeds of Pistacia vera would need to be placed in dry sand , just when ripe, otherwise the power of germination will be lost on the way to Australia. If you would cause M. Ajuti, to send me a list of all Australian plants growing already in […]
MS torn — one or two words missing.
garden , I will send supplemental [… .]
MS torn — one word missing. The Chevalier Biagi is always very obliging in effecting transits. So I shall continue to benefit from his courtesy. I have written this letter in English, which I write more fluently than French, altho I understand the latter language fully.

I shall be able to send you within a short time the vi vol. of my Fragmenta phytographiae Australiae, and I am glad to learn that your noble Flora Italiana is progressing so rapidly. I often make [use]
MS torn. of your definitions of the species of Coniferae in settling the nomenclature of the plants in this garden.
With deep regards, I beg to remain, dear Professor, your

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: Seeds of aquatic plants for my Garden lake would be very welcome.
Should any new Conifers fall into my hands I will at once send them to you.
